advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for Victornet, the net for Victor computers, based on Omninet.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Byte magazine</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #9</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Teleplay advert for the Teleng Colourstars<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.geocities.com/doubledragon0uk//Home.html" target="_blank">Double Dragon Retro Mess</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #5</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture was used to promote the educative potential of the TO-7/70. This poor student is studying economic politics... <br><br> As usual, no cables are shown... the tape recorder is thus useless... Will someone tell him ?</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Graphics examples of the optional graphic card.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The European Alternative'' ! <br><br> The Basis 108 was sold in France by BMI. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 2 <br><br> "The domestic computer, business class"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD (JULY, 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Eric Buczynski for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT SEPT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE BACK</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Oric opens a full world to you"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PC-60</strong></font><br><blockquote>Photo taken from a Commodore brochure.<br> Notice that the girl seems not to be interested at all in the computer...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUSTAR NETWORK</strong></font><br><blockquote>Compustar is the network version of the SuperBrain. Each SuperBrain computer became an 'intelligent' video terminal called a Video Processing Unit and containing its own microprocessor and 64 KB of RAM. Single or double floppy disc could be added for 350 KB to 1.5 MB local storage. Up to 255 terminals could be connected into the same network. Maximum cable length between two terminal was one mile at a 1.6 MB data transfer rate. Each of them could share a disk storage system, from 10 to 96 MB with CP/M operating system. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, the Victor 9000 features was compared with those of four competitor computers: IBM PC, Xerox 820, Apple III and TRS-80 Model II. <br><br> Victor features was definitely higher than all of the desktop computers of the time, including the IBM PC. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (NOV. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Enter the game of computing"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">Soichiro Oga</a> for this picture !</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/ </b></p></blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: Power on/off, Speed fast/slow, Ball angle 20?/40?, Bat size large/small, Service auto/manual
computer.description:
MBO, a popular German electronics manufacturer, produced a large serie of pong systems named "tele-ball" with numbers ranging from 1 to 9 (or more ?). Though they had some cosmetic differences, all these systems were very close to each other in terms of functionality.
The Tele-Ball IV is very similar to the Tele-Ball "I", though its display is in colour. This is the major difference. The plastic case is the same. Only vertical sliders on the controllers and a tiny red "service" button have been added onto the system.
Thus the Tele-Ball IV is basically the colour version of the Tele-Ball "I". It only plays the four basic pong games (tennis, hockey, squash and practice).
The two big silver dials on the front panel are used to switch the system on/off and to select games.
computer.keyboard: Two detachable controllers with knob and vertical slider
computer.name: Tele-Ball IV
computer.ports: RF TV video output, power in
computer.speed: Reset (big red button), Service (tiny red button)
